articles.headline: 3 at Comverse Charged in Stock Options Case
articles.snippet: The executives created a secret slush fund for fictitious employees to dole out options to favored employees.
articles.abstract: The executives created a secret slush fund for fictitious employees to dole out options to favored employees.
articles.lead_paragraph: Perhaps, in hindsight, naming a company account after “Phantom of the Opera” was not a good idea.

articles.headline: A Head Start on the Future of High-Def
articles.snippet: Next month, Canon will release the world’s smallest and least expensive high-definition tape camcorder.
articles.abstract: Next month, Canon will release the world’s smallest and least expensive high-definition tape camcorder.
articles.lead_paragraph: HIGH-TECH projects often take longer to complete than anticipated; just ask Microsoft’s Windows team.

articles.headline: There’s Money in Thirst
articles.snippet: Everyone knows there is a lot of money to be made in oil. But a fresh group of big businesses is discovering there may be even greater profit in a more prosaic liquid: water.
articles.abstract: Everyone knows there is a lot of money to be made in oil. But a fresh group of big businesses is discovering there may be even greater profit in a more prosaic liquid: water.
articles.lead_paragraph: Everyone knows there is a lot of money to be made in oil. But a fresh group of big businesses is discovering there may be even greater profit in a more prosaic liquid: water.

articles.headline: Hot Market for Second Homes Hits Slump
articles.snippet: As the overall housing market weakens, interest in buying vacation homes appears to be falling even faster.
articles.abstract: As the overall housing market weakens, interest in buying vacation homes appears to be falling even faster.
articles.lead_paragraph: WESTHAMPTON, N.Y. — The brand new 6,000-square-foot vacation home, backing on a boat dock on Moriches Bay, has been on the market for more than a year. After plenty of showings, but no offers, the investor who built the house recently cut the price twice, by a total of $600,000, to $4 million.

articles.headline: Israel, Seeking Rocket Buffer, Sets Expansion
articles.snippet: Israel approved a plan to expand ground operations in Lebanon, but delayed the offensive pending the outcome of diplomatic efforts.
articles.abstract: Israel approved a plan to expand ground operations in Lebanon, but delayed the offensive pending the outcome of diplomatic efforts.
articles.lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM, Aug. 9 — Israel decided Wednesday to move thousands more troops into Lebanon in a major expansion of its ground operation aimed at pushing Hezbollah and its rocket launchers farther away from Israeli cities.

articles.headline: On Patrol, Iraqis Prove Eager, Erratic and Green
articles.snippet: Two years after the start of an effort to train Iraqi security forces, many of the early troubles remain.
articles.abstract: Two years after the start of an effort to train Iraqi security forces, many of the early troubles remain.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Aug. 9 — The American soldiers stopped at the corner to watch 20 members of the Iraqi national police force search a Sunni mosque in Dawra, a violent neighborhood in southern Baghdad at the heart of the new American drive to secure the capital.

articles.headline: For Housing, a Finger in the Wind
articles.snippet: Sales of homes are falling, for-sale signs are sprouting across the nation’s front lawns and price increases have slowed to a crawl.
articles.abstract: Sales of homes are falling, for-sale signs are sprouting across the nation’s front lawns and price increases have slowed to a crawl.
articles.lead_paragraph: He would not go so far as to call it a bubble, but Alan Greenspan, in response to a question in the spring of 2005, acknowledged that there were signs of “froth” in the housing market.

articles.headline: Paulson Reinforces His Reach
articles.snippet: Treasury Secretary Henry M. Paulson Jr. is developing a new plan to confront China’s growing economic clout.
articles.abstract: Treasury Secretary Henry M. Paulson Jr. is developing a new plan to confront China’s growing economic clout.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 — Treasury Secretary Henry M. Paulson Jr. has spent his first weeks in office seeking to assert control within the administration over international economic issues, focusing in particular on developing a new plan to confront China’s growing economic clout, administration officials say.

articles.headline: An Oil Leak Rattles a State and Its Workers
articles.snippet: An oil field shutdown is cause for concern in Alaska, where most general fund revenue comes from industry taxes.
articles.abstract: An oil field shutdown is cause for concern in Alaska, where most general fund revenue comes from industry taxes.
articles.lead_paragraph: DEADHORSE, Alaska, Aug. 9 — There was a newspaper here once. It was back in the boom years of the 1980’s, when the crude oil surging up from 9,000 feet beneath the earth and ice was still transforming Alaska’s North Slope from Arctic wilderness to flush frontier.

articles.headline: Paulson Reinforces His Reach
articles.snippet: Treasury Secretary Henry M. Paulson Jr. has spent his first weeks in office seeking to assert control within the administration over international economic issues, focusing in particular on developing a new plan to confront China's growing economi...
articles.abstract: Treasury Secretary Henry M. Paulson Jr. has spent his first weeks in office seeking to assert control within the administration over international economic issues, focusing in particular on developing a new plan to confront China's growing economic clout, administration officials say.     With the encouragement of the White House, Mr. Paulson has been considering steps, including the establishment of an interagency working group on international economic issues led by the Treasury Department, to fulfill President Bush's pledge to make him the administration's chief economic policy maker.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 - Treasury Secretary Henry M. Paulson Jr. has spent his first weeks in office seeking to assert control within the administration over international economic issues, focusing in particular on developing a new plan to confront China's growing economic clout, administration officials say.

articles.headline: For Housing, a Finger in the Wind
articles.snippet: He would not go so far as to call it a bubble, but Alan Greenspan, in response to a question in the spring of 2005, acknowledged that there were signs of ''froth'' in the housing market.     More than a year later, the froth has all but disappeare...
articles.abstract: He would not go so far as to call it a bubble, but Alan Greenspan, in response to a question in the spring of 2005, acknowledged that there were signs of ''froth'' in the housing market.     More than a year later, the froth has all but disappeared: sales of homes are falling, for-sale signs are sprouting across the nation's front lawns and price increases have slowed to a crawl.
articles.lead_paragraph: He would not go so far as to call it a bubble, but Alan Greenspan, in response to a question in the spring of 2005, acknowledged that there were signs of "froth" in the housing market.

articles.headline: Rices Hurdles on Middle East Begin at Home
articles.snippet: As fighting was breaking out last month between Hezbollah and Israel, Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice worked through the night at her guest quarters on Russia's Baltic coast to draft America's response to the unfolding crisis.     The strategy...
articles.abstract: As fighting was breaking out last month between Hezbollah and Israel, Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice worked through the night at her guest quarters on Russia's Baltic coast to draft America's response to the unfolding crisis.     The strategy she outlined that night, the eve of the Group of 8 meeting, dispensed with traditional diplomatic flourishes. It included no call for an immediate cease-fire and expressly stated that Israel had a right to defend itself.

articles.headline: Hot Market for Second Homes Hits Slump
articles.snippet: The brand new 6,000-square-foot vacation home, backing on a boat dock on Moriches Bay, has been on the market for more than a year. After plenty of showings, but no offers, the investor who built the house recently cut the price twice, by a total ...
articles.abstract: The brand new 6,000-square-foot vacation home, backing on a boat dock on Moriches Bay, has been on the market for more than a year. After plenty of showings, but no offers, the investor who built the house recently cut the price twice, by a total of $600,000, to $4 million.     It has still not been sold. To be sure, the price reductions have created more interest, according to the agent representing the owner, and he now hopes that it will be sold right after Labor Day, a prime season for home transactions in the Hamptons.
articles.lead_paragraph: WESTHAMPTON, N.Y. - The brand new 6,000-square-foot vacation home, backing on a boat dock on Moriches Bay, has been on the market for more than a year. After plenty of showings, but no offers, the investor who built the house recently cut the price twice, by a total of $600,000, to $4 million.

articles.headline: Theres Money in Thirst
articles.snippet: Everyone knows there is a lot of money to be made in oil. But a fresh group of big businesses is discovering there may be even greater profit in a more prosaic liquid: water.      ''You've got exploding urban populations, increased pollution and a...
articles.abstract: Everyone knows there is a lot of money to be made in oil. But a fresh group of big businesses is discovering there may be even greater profit in a more prosaic liquid: water.      ''You've got exploding urban populations, increased pollution and a need to address those things in a meaningful way,'' said Ian Barbour, general manager of Dow Chemical's Water Solutions unit. ''Of course, we're investing significantly in the water business.''
articles.lead_paragraph: Everyone knows there is a lot of money to be made in oil. But a fresh group of big businesses is discovering there may be even greater profit in a more prosaic liquid: water.

articles.headline: A Head Start on the Future of High-Def
articles.snippet: HIGH-TECH projects often take longer to complete than anticipated; just ask Microsoft's Windows team.      But it seems as if we've been hearing about high-definition video since the Eisenhower administration. The Federal Communications Commission...
articles.abstract: HIGH-TECH projects often take longer to complete than anticipated; just ask Microsoft's Windows team.      But it seems as if we've been hearing about high-definition video since the Eisenhower administration. The Federal Communications Commission's mandatory cutoff of old-fashioned analog TV broadcasts, now scheduled for 2009, has been delayed, what, 500 times?
articles.lead_paragraph: HIGH-TECH projects often take longer to complete than anticipated; just ask Microsoft's Windows team.

articles.headline: An Oil Leak Rattles a State and Its Workers
articles.snippet: There was a newspaper here once. It was back in the boom years of the 1980's, when the crude oil surging up from 9,000 feet beneath the earth and ice was still transforming Alaska's North Slope from Arctic wilderness to flush frontier.     Now thi...
articles.abstract: There was a newspaper here once. It was back in the boom years of the 1980's, when the crude oil surging up from 9,000 feet beneath the earth and ice was still transforming Alaska's North Slope from Arctic wilderness to flush frontier.     Now this frontier town has no newspaper. Nor a resident mayor or town council or even any real residents. It is just a drill site with as many as 5,000 people -- no one seems to have a firm count -- who cycle in and out, year round, often on two-week hitches.
articles.lead_paragraph: DEADHORSE, Alaska, Aug. 9 - There was a newspaper here once. It was back in the boom years of the 1980's, when the crude oil surging up from 9,000 feet beneath the earth and ice was still transforming Alaska's North Slope from Arctic wilderness to flush frontier.

articles.headline: On Patrol, Iraqis Prove Eager, Erratic and Green
articles.snippet: The American soldiers stopped at the corner to watch 20 members of the Iraqi national police force search a Sunni mosque in Dawra, a violent neighborhood in southern Baghdad at the heart of the new American drive to secure the capital.      The fi...
articles.abstract: The American soldiers stopped at the corner to watch 20 members of the Iraqi national police force search a Sunni mosque in Dawra, a violent neighborhood in southern Baghdad at the heart of the new American drive to secure the capital.      The first camouflaged Iraqi emerged proudly with a quarter-pound of TNT, which he immediately delivered to the Americans. Others handed over evidence bordering on the bizarre: a roll of white string and a pink dress.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Aug. 9 - The American soldiers stopped at the corner to watch 20 members of the Iraqi national police force search a Sunni mosque in Dawra, a violent neighborhood in southern Baghdad at the heart of the new American drive to secure the capital.

articles.headline: 3 at Comverse Charged in Stock Options Case
articles.snippet: Perhaps, in hindsight, naming a company account after ''Phantom of the Opera'' was not a good idea.     Describing a brazen scheme to manipulate the granting of options, federal prosecutors in Brooklyn charged three former executives of Comverse T...
articles.abstract: Perhaps, in hindsight, naming a company account after ''Phantom of the Opera'' was not a good idea.     Describing a brazen scheme to manipulate the granting of options, federal prosecutors in Brooklyn charged three former executives of Comverse Technology with mail, securities and wire fraud yesterday. The three executives, prosecutors said, used fictitious employees to create a secret slush fund of options to be distributed to favored employees.
articles.lead_paragraph: Perhaps, in hindsight, naming a company account after "Phantom of the Opera" was not a good idea.
